metadata.title: Performance of hot and warm mix asphalt mixtures enhanced by nano-sized graphene oxide

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Construction and Building Materials
journal homepage: www.elsevier .com/locate /conbui ldmat
Performance of hot and warm mix asphalt mixtures enhanced by nano-sized graphene oxide
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.conbuildmat.2019.05.054 0950-0618/Published by Elsevier Ltd.
⇑ Corresponding authors. E-mail addresses: liukefei92013@163.com (K. Liu), xianming.shi@wsu.edu
(X. Shi). 1 These two authors made equal contributions to this work.
Juncai Zhu a,1, Kun Zhang b,1, Kefei Liu a,c,⇑, Xianming Shi c,⇑ a School of Civil Engineering, Central South University of Forestry & Technology, Changsha 410004, Hunan, PR China bDepartment of Civil Engineering, California State University, Chico, CA 95929, USA cDepartment of Civil and Environmental Engineering, Voiland College of Engineering and Architecture, Washington State University, P.O. Box 642714, Pullman, WA 99164, USA
h i g h l i g h t s
The modification effects of graphene oxide combined with different warm mix additives on asphalt mixtures are studied. Graphene oxide has significant benefits on the moisture resistance and high-temperature rutting resistance of asphalt mixtures. Waste cooking oil can effectively improve the thermal cracking resistance of GO-modified asphalt mixture. Graphene oxide can effectively improve the (oxidative) aging resistance of asphalt mixture.
a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 19 January 2019 Received in revised form 30 April 2019 Accepted 7 May 2019 Available online 16 May 2019
Keywords: Graphene oxide (GO) Warm mix asphalt (WMA) Waste cooking oil (WCO) Moisture susceptibility Performance evaluation
a b s t r a c t
The objective of this laboratory study was to evaluate the performance of hot mix asphalt (HMA) and warm mix asphalt (WMA) mixtures modified by graphene oxide (GO). The base asphalt has a 60/80 penetration grade and the warmmix additives are Sasobit and waste cooking oil (WCO), which were added at 3% and 5% by weight of asphalt binder, respectively. The performance of HMA and WMA mixtures was evaluated. The experimental results indicate that the addition of GO at 0.05% by weight of binder significantly increased the mixing and compaction temperatures of base asphalt mixture, whereas the addition of warm mix additive, either Sasobit or WCO, can effectively reduce the construction temperatures of GO modified asphalt mixture. The addition of GO can significantly improve the moisture resistance, hightemperature rutting resistance, and compressive resilient modulus of asphalt mixture, but slightly compromise its low-temperature cracking resistance. In addition, Sasobit can compatibly work with GO to improve the performance of asphalt mixtures, and WCO can effectively improve the low-temperature cracking resistance of GO modified asphalt mixture. Aging test results showed that GO can enhance the (oxidative) aging resistance of asphalt mixtures, reduce the moisture susceptibility of the aged mixtures, and mitigate the detrimental impact of aging on their low-temperature performance.
Published by Elsevier Ltd.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
In the last decade, a variety of nano-sized materials, e.g. nano montmorillonite [1], nano zinc oxide [2], nano TiO2 and nanosilica [3], have been studied for their use to modify asphalt binders. The effects of these nano-materials on the performance of asphalt binders and mixtures were analyzed. From the research results, these traditional nano-materials have positive effects on the high-temperature rutting resistance, mechanical properties and
resistance to moisture damage of asphalt mixture, but their typical contents are between 4% and 6% of base binders [1–3], which is not cost-effective and may cause non-uniform dispersion issues.
Graphene oxide (GO) is a novel carbon based nano-material with excellent reaction characteristics, high specific surface area, and rich surface polar oxygen-containing groups [4]. GO has been demonstrated to effectively modify polymer-based materials, such as coatings [5,6], resins [7], and rubbers [8], and enhance their engineering performances. Recent studies were focused on the potential applications of GO in building materials, and demonstrated the benefits of GO to improve the compressive, split tensile and flexural strengths of concrete materials [9–11] and their durability [12,13].
GO has been recently reported capable of very effectively modifying some asphalt binders at a very low dosage, such as 0.05% by weight of binder [14,15]. Our exploratory work [14,15] revealed that the modification mechanism of GO for a non-modified binder includes both chemical reactions and physical blending, but only physical blending for a styrene-butadiene-styrene (SBS)-modified binder. The binder test results suggested that GO can significantly improve the high-temperature performance of asphalt binders, but not their low-temperature cracking resistance. While the binder tests results are promising, additional evaluations of asphalt mixtures are needed to investigate the modification effects of this novel nano-material on the pavement performance parameters at the low dosage rate of 0.05%.
In this context, this study aims to evaluate the pavement performance of hot mix asphalt (HMA) and warm mix asphalt (WMA) modified by a trace amount of GO. Specifically, different types of HMA and WMA mixtures were prepared in laboratory, and the effects of GO on the properties of these mixtures were analyzed by a series of tests. The WMA additives used in this study include Sasobit and waste cooking oil (WCO). They are used to reduce emissions and energy consumptions by decreasing mixing and compaction temperatures of mixtures, without significantly reducing the performance of pavement [16–18].

sections.heading: 2.1.1. Base materials
sections.text:
2.1.1.1. Asphalt. In this study, an asphalt with the penetration grade of 60/80 (simply referred to as AH-70) was used as the control asphalt, which was provided by Gaofu Oil Company (Hunan, P.R. China). The AH-70 asphalt binder is an unmodified binder and its properties are shown in Table 1 (as A0) and in Fig. 1(a).
2.1.1.2. Additives. The GO was produced from 325 mesh flake graphite following the Hummers method in laboratory [4,19], featuring an extremely high specific surface area ( 2600 m2/g). The GO adopted in this study features a zeta potential of 30 mV in the neutral aqueous solution as a result of negatively charged functional groups on the nanolayers [20]. At this zeta potential, the GO in the aqueous solution is well dispersed in the form of mainly monolayers, each with a C/O ratio of 1.7, thickness of 0.8–1.1 nm and average lateral size of 1 mm [21]. The FTIR spectrum of the GO is shown in Fig. 1(b). Before adding GO into asphalt binder, the laboratory-fabricated GO was a viscous liquid and dried to a paste in a 60 C water bath. Then, the paste was dried in a ventilated oven at 120 C for 4 h to a black powder. Based on our previous asphalt binder study, the optimum dosage of GO to modify the asphalt was 0.05% by weight of asphalt binder [14].
Two warm mix additives, Sasobit and waste cooking oil (WCO), were used to prepare WMA binders and mixtures. The Sasobit used in this study was a high melting-point organic additive produced by Sasol Wax, Germany. According to the manufacturer’s recommendation, the optimum content is 3% by the weight of asphalt binder, and the physical and chemical properties of Sasobit are shown in Table 2 and Fig. 1(c).
The WCO used in this paper was provided by a food supermarket named Better Life (Hunan, P.R. China), and its basic properties are shown in Table 3 and Fig. 1(d).
2.1.1.3. Aggregates. In this study, basalt and limestone chips were used as the coarse aggregate and fine aggregate, respectively. The properties of each aggregate are shown in Table 4. The mineral filler is limestone powder, and all the properties of aggregates and mineral filler meet the technical requirements of specification JTG F40-2004 [22].

sections.heading: 2.1.2. Sample preparation
sections.text: To compare the performance of different asphalt binders and mixtures, six asphalt binders were prepared and evaluated. The composition and code of each asphalt binder are shown in Table 1. The dosages of GO, Sasobit, andWCO used in this study were 0.05%, 3% and 5% by weight of asphalt binder, respectively, which were based on the results of previous experiments and manufacturer’s recommendations. The flowchart of the preparation of modified asphalt binders is presented in Fig. 2, and a photo of the sample preparation is shown in Fig. 3.

sections.heading: 2.1.3. Mix design
sections.text: According to the Technical Specifications for Construction of Highway Asphalt Pavements of China (JTG F40-2004) [22], a coarse continuous graded asphalt mixture (AC-C) with the nominal maximum size of 13.2 mm was designed, which is usually used in the surface layer of pavement. Fig. 4 shows the aggregate gradation used in this study. Based on the designed air voids of 4.0%, the optimum asphalt binder content was determined to be 4.9%. All evaluated mixtures in this study had the same gradation and optimum asphalt content. To simplify the expression, the asphalt mixtures using A0, A1, A4, and A5 asphalt binders are referred to as HMA1, HMA-2, WMA-1 and WMA-2, respectively.

sections.heading: 2.1.4. Determination of mixing and compaction temperatures
sections.text:
According to the specification JTG F40-2004, the mixing and compaction temperatures for the asphalt mixture can be determined based on the viscosity-temperature curve, whereas the temperature corresponding binder viscosity of (0.17 ± 0.02) Pa s is used for mixing and that of (0.28 ± 0.03) Pa s for compaction, respectively [23]. In this work, the mixing and compaction temperatures for the control asphalt mixture (HMA-1) were determined and presented in Table 5. However, the modified asphalt binders
containing additives tend to feature significant non-linear or nonNewtonian properties [24], their mixing and compaction temperatures are thus higher than the actual construction temperature if
the principle of equal viscosity of binder is adopted, which results in aging of asphalt [25]. Therefore, for HMA-2, the compaction temperature and volume curve were drawn by the density test of compacted asphalt mixture. This test was carried out on the gyratory compacted specimen formed at different temperatures to obtain the best compaction temperature. Then, the viscositytemperature curve was established based on the relationship between viscosity and shear rate of A1 (GO modified asphalt binder). Finally, the mixing and compaction temperature of HMA-2 corresponding to mixing viscosity (0.17 ± 0.02) Pa s and compaction viscosity (0.28 ± 0.03) Pa s were fixed on the curve [26,27]. The results are shown in Table 5.
For WMA, the viscosity-temperature curve of asphalt is not suitable for determine the mixing and compaction temperatures [28]. For a given asphalt binder, aggregate, compaction method and compaction work, the volumetric parameters of asphalt mixture (e.g., percent air void) are a function of temperature. Therefore, the (percent) air void was employed to determine the compaction temperature of the mixture (based on the principle of equal volume of mixture). The power function was employed for fitting, and the air voids at different compaction temperatures were measured and the power function was plotted to calculate the values of each parameter when the air void is 4.0%. As such, the average compaction temperature was obtained. Finally, the results of mixing and compaction temperatures of each WMA mixture confirmed by the principle of equal volume of mixture are shown in Table 5.

sections.heading: 2.2. Testing methods
sections.text: To evaluate the effect of modifiers (GO, Sasobit, and WCO) on the moisture susceptibility, high-temperature stability, lowtemperature cracking resistance, mechanical strengths, and aging performance of HMA and WMA mixtures, laboratory tests were conducted according to the specification JTG E20-2011 [23].

sections.heading: 2.2.1. Moisture susceptibility test
sections.text:
The Immersion Marshall test and freeze-thaw splitting test were used together to evaluate the resistance of asphalt mixtures to moisture damage. The Marshall specimens were compacted with the diameter of 101.6 mm and height of 63.5 mm. The number of blow on both sides was 75 for Immersion Marshall test and 50 for freeze-thaw splitting test, respectively.
2.2.1.1. Immersion Marshall test. The residual stability (RS) was characterized by the ratio of Immersed Marshall stability (MS1) to Marshall stability (MS) to characterize the moisture susceptibility of asphalt mixtures. To obtain MS and MS1, the Marshall specimens were divided into two groups and placed in a 60 C water bath for 30 min. and 48 h, respectively. And then, the Marshall stabilization apparatus was used to determine MS and MS1 following the ASTM D6926 [29] with the loading rate of 50 mm/min.
2.2.1.2. Freeze-thaw splitting test. The splitting strength of each HMA and WMA mixture was tested by the freeze–thaw splitting test. Eight specimens were separated into two groups. One group was stored at room temperature as control specimens and kept in water bath at 25 C for 2 h before the splitting test. Another group was placed in a chamber at 18 C for 16 h; then the specimens were immersed in a constant temperature water bath at 60 C for 24 h; finally, the specimens were kept in a tank at 25 C for 2 h before the splitting test. The splitting tensile strength (RT) of each sample was obtained under the loading rate of 50 mm/ min. The RT values of room temperature cured specimens and freeze-thaw cured specimens were recorded as RT1 and RT2,
Table 3 Basic properties of WCO.

Fig. 2. Preparation process flowchart for modified asphalt binders.
respectively. The tensile strength ratio (TSR) of a mixture was calculated as follows.
TSR ¼ RT2 RT1
ð1Þ

sections.heading: 2.2.2. Wheel tracking test
sections.text: The high-temperature performance of asphalt mixture was evaluated by the dynamic stability (DS) using the wheel tracking test. According to the specification [23], the sample size was 300 mm 300 mm 50 mm. After conditioning the sample at 60 C for 6 h, the wheel tracking test was performed under the wheel load of 0.7 MPa at 60 C. DS was determined as the number of standard loads that cause an asphalt mixture to deform 1 mm at the temperature of 60 C. The higher the DS value, the better the ability of an asphalt mixture to resist permanent deformation.

sections.heading: 2.2.3. Uniaxial compression test
sections.text:
The uniaxial compression test was employed to measure the compressive resilient modulus (CRM) and compressive strength (CS) of the asphalt mixtures. The test was carried out at 20 C and 15 C respectively, and each test sample was kept in a specified
temperature (20 C or 15 C) water bath for 2.5 h before test. The loading rate was 2 mm/min. Six specimens of each asphalt mixture were prepared to ensure reliability of the test results. The test procedure used is described as follows: (1) determine the failure load of specimens using a universal testing machine, and then determine the average CS value of each mixture; (2) for each asphalt mixture, the average CS value is divided into 10 grades, and 0.1CS, 0.2CS, 0.3CS, 0.4CS, 0.5CS, 0.6CS and 0.7CS are used as test loads for CRM; (3) after eliminating the influence of eccentric compression, starting from 0.1CS, the load and unload process is repeated for each testing load, and the actual load qi and resilient deformation Dli under each load are recorded; and (4) adjust the origin of qi Dli curve according to the specification. Then, the CRM value of each asphalt mixture is calculated as follows.
CRM ¼ q5 h Dl5
ð2Þ
where q5 is the load strength corresponding to the 0.5CS (MPa), h is the axial height of specimen (mm), and Dl5 is the resilient deformation corresponding to the 0.5CS (mm).

sections.heading: 2.2.4. Three-point bending beam test
sections.text: The three-point bending beam test was employed to determine the low-temperature cracking resistance of the asphalt mixtures. The test temperature was 10 C. The beam specimens (250 mm 30 mm 35 mm) were sawed from the wheel tracking test sample (detailed in section 3.2). The specimens were placed in a thermostatic flume at 10 C for 2 h before this test. The loading velocity was 50 mm/min and the displacements were measured by a linear variable displacement transducer. The maximum bending strain (eB) at the bottom of beam was recorded when the specimen was damaged. The larger value of eB represents a better resistance to the low-temperature cracking.

sections.heading: 2.2.5. Shear strength test
sections.text:
The shear performance of asphalt mixture under specified temperature and loading conditions was measured by a triaxial tester to evaluate its high-temperature stability. The sample size is u100 150 mm, the test temperature is 60 C, and the sample was kept at 60 C for 5 h before testing. The specific testing process is as follows: (1) the preheated sample is filmed and placed in the pressure chamber of the tester, after sealing, oiling and cleaning, keep warm for 10 min; (2) four levels of confining pressures are set in the test system, which are 0 kPa, 138 kPa, 276 kPa and 414 kPa, respectively; (3) load is applied at a constant rate of 7.5 mm/min, the axial pressure, axial deformation and volumetric deformation are recorded simultaneously; (4) when the axial pressure peaks, stop the test; (5) parallel tests of confining pressures at all levels are on at least three specimens.
Axial strain e1, section area Aa and maximum principal stress r1 are calculated as follows.
e1 ¼ Dhh0 ð3Þ
Aa ¼ V0 þ DVh0 Dh ð4Þ
r1 ¼ PAa 10þ r3 ð5Þ
where Dh is the vertical deformation of the specimen during compression (mm), h0 is the initial height of the specimen (cm), Aa is the actual section area of the specimen during compression (cm2), V0 is the initial volume of the specimen (cm3), DV is the volume change of the specimen during compression (cm3),r3 is the confining pressure (kPa), P is the axial load (N).

sections.heading: 2.2.6. Aging test
sections.text:
The durability of asphalt mixture was also evaluated by the low-temperature cracking resistance and moisture susceptibility of the asphalt mixtures after aging. According to JTG E20-2011 [23], the short-term aging entails placing the loose mixture in the ventilated oven at the temperature of 135 C for 4 h to simulate the aging of asphalt mixture during mixing and paving at the construction site, whereas the long-term aging entails putting the specimens (which were molded after short-term aging) into a ven-
tilated and heated oven at 85 C for 10 days to simulate the aging of asphalt mixture during the service life of pavement. The moisture susceptibility test and three-point bending beam test were conducted on the aged specimens, and the effects of asphalt modifiers (GO, Sasobit, and WCO) on the aging performance were evaluated by comparing the test results between aged and unaged samples.
Fig. 5 showed the experimental setups of these test.

sections.heading: 3.1. Properties of asphalt binders
sections.text:
The effect of different modifiers on the properties of base asphalt is shown in Table 1. The addition of GO at 0.05 wt% reduced the penetration of the base asphalt by 32.5%, increased its softening point by 25%, and slightly decreased its ductility. The extent of modification effects of Sasobit (at 3 wt%) on the base asphalt was similar to GO (at 0.05 wt%). However, Sasobit exhibited greater influence on the softening point and less influence on the ductility. WCO showed completely opposite influences on the base asphalt. The addition of WCO at 5 wt% increased the penetration of the base asphalt by 15% and reduced its softening point by 20%. In other words, both GO and Sasobit can improve the stiffness of base asphalt and its high-temperature stability, but GO has a certain extent adverse effect on the cracking resistance at low temperature.
When the GO/Sasobit composite additives were used together, this reduced the penetration of the base asphalt by 61.7%, increased its softening point by 76.7%, and decreased its ductility by about 14%. Meanwhile, it increased the viscosity of the base asphalt by 33.1% at the temperature of 135 C. The compositemodified asphalt binder (A4) features strong stiffness and excellent high-temperature performance, but was not ideal for lowtemperature cracking resistance or workability. In comparison,
the GO/WCO composite modified asphalt binder (A5) has slightly lower penetration and slightly higher softening point than the base asphalt (A0), and its ductility and workability shows no significant loss.
In addition, for the GO modified asphalt binder (A1), it has the lowest mass loss and the second highest penetration ratio (98.25%) after TFOT short-term aging. This suggests that GO can effectively mitigate the performance degradation due to shortterm aging to benefit the durability and prolong the service life of asphalt pavement. The effect of Sasobit on the short-term aging of the base asphalt is similar to that of GO, while to a lesser extent. On the contrary, the addition of WCO at 5 wt% resulted in a higher mass loss of asphalt binder and great reduction in penetration, which is indicative of compromised resistance to the short-term aging. It is noteworthy that the trend in short-term aging induced property changes of the asphalt binder modified by GO and warm mix additive is similar to that of the asphalt binder modified by warm mix additive alone.

sections.heading: 3.2. Moisture susceptibility of asphalt mixtures
sections.text:
Figs. 6 and 7 present the results of Immersion Marshall test and Freeze-thaw splitting test of the four asphalt mixtures. From these tests, the increases in the RS and TSR values correspond to the improvement of the resistance of asphalt mixture to moisture damage.
Fig. 6 reveals the positive effects of GO and Sasobit and the negative effects of WCO on the Marshall stability of asphalt mixtures. The MS1 value of all asphalt mixtures was less than MS, indicating that exposure to water compromised the structure of asphalt mixtures and thus reduce their stability. Compared with HMA-1, the MS and MS1 values of HMA-2 increased by 39.1% and 39.9%, respectively, suggesting that GO (at 0.05% by weight of binder) sig-
nificantly improved the stability of the asphalt mixture. The MS and MS1 values of WMA-1 were 45.2% and 45.8% higher than those of HMA-1, respectively, suggesting that the composite of GO (at 0.05 wt%) and Sasobit (at 3 wt%) can further improve the stability of the asphalt mixture. In comparison, the corresponding values of WMA-2 were only 10.8% and 11.3% higher than those of HMA1, indicating that the addition of WCO (at 5% by weight of binder) could offset the benefits on the stability of the asphalt mixture by using GO. In addition, The RS results (Fig. 6) indicate that the use of GO, either individually or in combination with warm mix additive, can effectively improve the resistance of asphalt mixture to moisture damage. Specifically, the RS value of each asphalt mixture was ranked as: HMA-2 (97.84%) > WMA-1 (97.71%) > WMA-2 (97.67%) > HMA-1 (97.31%).
Fig. 7 reveals that GO and Sasobit can both significantly improve the splitting tensile strength of asphalt mixture, especially after the freeze-thaw conditions, whereas WCO can weaken the splitting tensile strength of GO modified asphalt mixture. Compared with HMA-1, the RT1 and RT2 values of HMA-2 were increased by 41.4% and 64.0%, and those values of WMA-1 increased by 56.0% and 73.7%, respectively. The TSR values confirm the trends indicated by the strength data. The TSR values of HMA-2, WMA-1 and WMA-2 were increased by 13.31%, 9.32% and 7.97%, respectively, when compared with that of HMA-1.
To reduce the moisture susceptibility of asphalt mixture, efforts can be focused on improving either the cohesion between asphalt molecules or the adhesion between asphalt-aggregate molecules [1,30]. GO brings unique benefits in both aspects, owing to the large specific surface area of GO and abundant oxygen-containing groups on its surface. It is easy for GO to form hydrogen bonds and generate van der Waals force with the components in base asphalt, leading to greater cohesion than the base asphalt. In addition, GO can improve the crosslinking density of asphalt binder, thus improving the cohesion between asphalt molecules [14]. The surface of GO modified asphalt has higher surface energy and adhesion work, which improves the binder-aggregate bonding in the asphalt mixture. In other words, GO can work to mitigate the two main mechanisms of moisture damage, i.e., the loss of internal cohesion of asphalt and the loss of adhesion between asphalt and aggregate.
In general, the addition of Sasobit can lock the saturated oil and wax components in the GO modified asphalt, thereby improving the moisture resistance of the asphalt mixture [31]. Contrarily, WCO can notably reduce the cohesion of asphalt molecules [32] and thus lead to the moisture susceptibility of the asphalt mixture.

sections.heading: 3.3. High-temperature stability of asphalt mixtures
sections.text:
The GO modified asphalt mixture has excellent rutting resistance at high temperature. The addition of Sasobit further improves the high-temperature stability of the mixture, whereas the addition of WCO compromises it. This is illustrated by the DS results of different asphalt mixtures in Fig. 8. Specifically, the DS values of HMA-2, WMA-1 and WMA-2 were 102.9%, 163.0% and 22.4% higher than that of HMA-1, respectively.
The benefit of GO to the high-temperature stability of asphalt mixtures can be attributed to the physical and chemical reactions between GO nano-platelets and asphalt molecules. These interactions increase the cohesion of asphalt and facilitate the formation of a more stable system, thus requiring a higher amount of external force or energy to induce the same level of deformation [14].
Sasobit can crystallize at its melting-point temperature, which improves the stiffness of asphalt and thus the rutting resistance of asphalt mixture [33]. In the meantime, the addition of Sasobit can reduce the mixing and compaction temperatures of asphalt mixture (as shown in Table 5), thus reducing the aging of asphalt
binder during construction and extending the service life of mixture [34,35]. In comparison, the main components of WCO are unsaturated fatty acids. The addition of WCO thus decreases the cohesion and stiffness of asphalt binder and weakens the binderaggregate bonding of mixture [36], resulting in lower stability of the mixture at high temperature.

sections.heading: 3.4. Compressive resilient modulus of asphalt mixtures
sections.text:
The CRM value of an asphalt mixture is the ratio of the stress and resilient strain of the material under a slow loading speed. This value is not only an index describing the elastic-plastic deformation of materials under pressure, but also an important parameter reflecting the anti-deformation ability of asphalt mixture [37]. The asphalt mixture with a higher CRM value has a better deformation resistance.
The temperature sensitivity of mixture can be reduced by adding GO alone or the combined usage with Sasobit, while the temperature sensitivity of mixture will be increased by adding WCO. In other words, the additions of GO and Sasobit can improve the rigidity of the asphalt mixture and reduce the permanent deformation of asphalt pavement to extend its service life. These are illustrated by the results of the uniaxial compression test at 15 C and 20 C in Fig. 9. It shows that the mechanical properties of asphalt mixtures are susceptible to temperature. In addition, at the same temperature, the CRM values of each mixture are sorted as follows: WMA-1 > HMA-2 > WMA-2 > HMA-1, indicating that both GO and Sasobit can improve the mechanical properties of the mixture, while WCO has a negative effect.

sections.heading: 3.5. Low-temperature cracking resistance of asphalt mixtures
sections.text: Both GO and Sasobit can improve the rigidity of the mixture, but slightly reduce its cracking resistance at low temperature. The addition of WCO can significantly improve the stress relaxation ability of the mixture, so it can remarkably promote the low-temperature cracking resistance of the mixture. Specifically, Fig. 10 illustrates the effect of additives on the low-temperature performance of the asphalt mixture. Compared with HMA-1, the eB values of HMA-2 and WMA-1 decreased by 2.71% and 10.03% respectively, and the eB value of WMA-2 increased by 16.22%. The eB values of all the mixtures meet the requirement (>2000) of the specification [28].

sections.heading: 3.6. Shear performance of asphalt mixtures
sections.text:
With the principal stress as the abscissa and the shear stress as the ordinate, the Mohr’s circles under different confining pressures use the point (r1 + r3i)/2 as the center of the circle and (r1 r3i)/2
as the radius, and the envelope of the Mohr’s circles takes shape. The inclination angle of the envelope is the internal friction angle u, and the intercept of the envelope in the longitudinal coordinates is the cohesive force c, as shown in Fig. 11. The formula for calculating the shear strength of asphalt mixturesf is as follows.
sf ¼ c þ rtan/ ð6Þ where r is the principal stress value determined according to the actual pavement load. Formula (6) shows that the higher the shear parameters c and u, the better the shear performance of asphalt mixture. The test results of shear performance of each asphalt mixture are provided in Table 6.
Compared with HMA-1, the c and u values of HMA-2 increased by 45.19% and 6.93%, respectively, indicating that GO can improve the shear strength of asphalt mixture. That is, GO can improve the high-temperature performance of the asphalt mixture. This finding
is consistent with the wheel tracking results. One reason is that the addition of GO increased the viscosity of the asphalt binder. When the mixture is subjected to shear, the viscosity of asphalt binder is directly correlated with the shear resistance of asphalt mixture. Highly-viscous asphalt endows the mixture with greater viscous resistance and thus higher shear strength [38].
Compared with HMA-2, c and u values of WMA-1 increased by 20.45% and 3.94%, respectively, while c and u values of WMA-2 decreased by 24.26% and 4.79%, respectively. The results reveal that the shear strength of GO modified asphalt mixture can be improved by adding Sasobit. The reason is that Sasobit can crystallize at 60 C, which improves the hardness and cohesion of asphalt binder, and thus improves the high-temperature stability of asphalt mixture [33]. On the contrary, the addition of WCO reduced the shear strength of the GO modified asphalt mixture. The reason is that the addition of WCO reduces the cohesion and viscosity of GO modified asphalt binder, thus decreasing the shear strength of asphalt mixture.

sections.heading: 3.7. Mixture performance after short-term and long-term aging
sections.text:
Figs. 12 and 13 present the results of moisture susceptibility test for each asphalt mixture after short-term and long-term aging, respectively. The stability and splitting tensile strength of mixtures increased after aging, which is due to the thermo-oxidative effect. Specifically, the content of oxygen-containing polar functional groups of asphalt was increased due to aging and the asphalt binder becomes more brittle and hardening with a higher stiffness [39]. After aging, the RS values of HMA-2, WMA-1 and WMA-2 increased by 7.94%, 1.17% and 0.44% respectively, and TSR values were increased by 2.20%, 1.20% and 1.34% respectively. It indicates that the moisture resistance of GO modified asphalt mixtures can be effectively improved after aging. However, the aging reduced the DS and TSR values of HMA-1 by 3.45% and 4.21% respectively, indicative of lower resistance to moisture damage. Therefore, GO can improve the aging resistance of asphalt mixtures so as to improve its moisture resistance. When GO is combined with Sasobit or WCO, there has a certain reduction on the improvement of resistance to the moisture damage after aging.
Aging can weaken the resistance of asphalt mixture to lowtemperature cracking, as shown in Fig. 14. The eB values of HMA1, HMA-2, WMA-1 and WMA-2 decreased by 10.37%, 5.56%, 2.57%, and 21.72%, respectively after aging. This reflects that GO can effectively resist the influence of aging on the lowtemperature performance of asphalt mixtures, and this resistance effect is better when combined with Sasobit. The eB value of WMA-2 decreased most after aging, suggesting that the aging has the greatest influence on low-temperature cracking resistance of asphalt mixture containing WCO.
In light of aging test results, one likely reason that GO can effectively resist the effects of aging on the moisture susceptibility and low-temperature performance of asphalt mixtures is as follows. The GO can form a stable system and dense layered structure after its reaction with asphalt. The layered structure can effectively resist the destructive effect of aging on mixtures and prevent the volatilization of light components in asphalt, thereby increasing the content of structural asphalt in mixtures. This, in turn, slows down the decrease of moisture resistance and low-temperature cracking resistance of the asphalt mixture [14,40]. The enhance-
ment of Sasobit is similar to GO, mainly through increasing binderaggregate bonding and reducing volatilization of light components, both of which reduce the adverse impact of aging on the pavement performance of the mixture [41]. However, the light unsaturated fatty acids in WCO can volatilize in the aging process, which leads to the decrease of absorbed binder in the mixture and affects its pavement performance [15].

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
To investigate the modification effect of GO on asphalt mixtures, one HMA and two WMA mixtures modified by GO were prepared in the laboratory. The control mixture was produced with
AC-C using the same aggregate source and gradation. Performance-oriented tests, including moisture susceptibility, high-temperature rutting resistance, compressive resilient modulus, and low-temperature beam test, were conducted to evaluate the characteristics of HMAs and WMAs. The following conclusions were drawn based upon the experimental results obtained from this study:
1. The addition of GO can significantly increase the viscosity of the base asphalt, and thus increase the mixing and compaction temperatures. Addition of warm mix additives, e.g., Sasobit and WCO, can effectively reduce the mixing and compaction temperatures of the GO modified asphalt mixture. 2. The addition of GO at 0.05% by weight of asphalt binder can decrease the penetration and ductility of base asphalt, increase its softening point, and improve the durability of asphalt binder. The modification effects can be further enhanced by the combined use of GO and Sasobit. However, the combined use of GO and WCO can weaken the modification effects of GO. 3. The addition of GO at 0.05% by weight of asphalt binder can significantly improve the moisture resistance, high-temperature rutting resistance, compressive resilient modulus of asphalt mixture, and slightly compromise its low-temperature cracking resistance. The addition of Sasobit can further promote the resistance to moisture damage, high-temperature property and mechanical strength of the GO modified asphalt mixture. The addition of WCO can obviously improve the lowtemperature cracking resistance of GO modified asphalt mixture. Therefore, the combined use of GO and Sasobit is recommended for modifying asphalt mixtures that are used in hot areas, whereas the combined use of GO and WCO is recommended for modifying asphalt mixtures that are used in cold regions. 4. The addition of GO at 0.05% by weight of asphalt binder can enhance the aging resistance of asphalt mixture, reduce the moisture susceptibility of the aged mixtures, and weaken the influence of aging on its low-temperature performance. The combination of GO and Sasobit can further prevent the adverse effects of aging on asphalt mixture. However, the addition of WCO makes the GO modified asphalt mixture more agingsusceptible.
Declaration of Competing Interest
None.

Graphene oxide (GO) is a novel carbon based nano-material with excellent reaction characteristics, high specific surface area, and rich surface polar oxygen-containing groups [4].
GO has been demonstrated to effectively modify polymer-based materials, such as coatings [5,6], resins [7], and rubbers [8], and enhance their engineering performances.

metadata.abstractText: The objective of this laboratory study was to evaluate the performance of hot mix asphalt (HMA) and warm mix asphalt (WMA) mixtures modified by graphene oxide (GO). The base asphalt has a 60/80 penetration grade and the warmmix additives are Sasobit and waste cooking oil (WCO), which were added at 3% and 5% by weight of asphalt binder, respectively. The performance of HMA and WMA mixtures was evaluated. The experimental results indicate that the addition of GO at 0.05% by weight of binder significantly increased the mixing and compaction temperatures of base asphalt mixture, whereas the addition of warm mix additive, either Sasobit or WCO, can effectively reduce the construction temperatures of GO modified asphalt mixture. The addition of GO can significantly improve the moisture resistance, hightemperature rutting resistance, and compressive resilient modulus of asphalt mixture, but slightly compromise its low-temperature cracking resistance. In addition, Sasobit can compatibly work with GO to improve the performance of asphalt mixtures, and WCO can effectively improve the low-temperature cracking resistance of GO modified asphalt mixture. Aging test results showed that GO can enhance the (oxidative) aging resistance of asphalt mixtures, reduce the moisture susceptibility of the aged mixtures, and mitigate the detrimental impact of aging on their low-temperature performance. Published by Elsevier Ltd.
metadata.creator: Elsevier
